newsitem.title: USA: Stocks hold their ground; little tax selling seen.
newsitem.headline: Stocks hold their ground; little tax selling seen.

text.p: Stocks found their footing in early trading Thursday as an expected wave of tax-related selling on a proposed capital gains tax cut failed to materialise.
Shortly after 10 a.m. EDT, the Dow Jones industrial average, which tumbled 140 points Wednesday, was up 8.43 points at 7,094.08.
Stocks were expected to be hammered following news late Wednesday that the proposed capital gains tax, as part of a proposed federal budget agreement, would be effective May 7.
Republican chairmen of the congressional tax-writing committees said they would propose setting that date as the effective date for a lower capital gains tax.

The tax cut is expected to be part of a tax package this year and was included in a broad outline of a budget agreement to balance the budget by 2002 reached Friday between congressional leaders and the White House.

"There is still not a guarantee that the tax cut will go into effect," said Ricky Harrington, technical analyst at Interstate/Johnson Lane. "Other factors are outweighing it, such as strong economic momentum.

"I was surprised that the market came back over the past couple of weeks. It's still in a manic phase," he said. "If volume slows on pullbacks and no selling comes in, you could get another move higher.
"But the situation is fluid," Harrington added. "Volatile. The only thing you can be sure of is that this volatility will continue."
Investors did not rush to sell, and it appeared that Wall Street was putting a positive spin on the tax angle of the proposed budget deal.
Longer-term, the tax cut will be bullish for stocks, analysts said.
Analysts expect the current top capital gains tax rate of 28 percent will end up anywhere from the 19.8 percent that Senate Republicans proposed early this year to 21 percent.
Senate Majority Leader Trent Lott has said there would be room to cut the top rate to under 20 percent.
Stocks also tracked bonds, which rallied on news that weekly jobless claims held steady, a possible sign that the economy's growth was slowing.
The Labour Department said 347,000 Americans filed for new jobless benefits in the week ended May 3. That figure was unchanged from the previous week.
The only time claims were higher this year was in the week ended Jan. 4, when they stood at 365,000.
Wall Street economists had forecast initial claims of 334,000 for the latest week.
Analysts said that the direction of interest rates would be a more important near-term factor for the stock market than the capital gains tax reduction.
